verses.text:
Then Mordecai prayed to the Lord, recalling all the works of the Lord, and said, "O Lord, Lord, you rule as King over all things, for the universe is in your power and no one can oppose you when it is your will to save Israel. You made heaven and earth and every wondrous thing under heaven. You are Lord of all, and there is no one who can resist you, the Lord. You know all things; you know, O Lord, that it was not in insolence or pride or for any love of glory that I refused to bow down to proud Haman, for I would have been willing to kiss the soles of his feet to save Israel! But I did this so that I might not set human glory above the glory of God; and I will not bow down to anyone but you, who are my Lord, nor act in pride. And now, O Lord God and King, God of Abraham, spare your people; for the eyes of our foes are upon us to annihilate us, and they desire to destroy your inheritance, which has been yours from the beginning. Do not neglect your portion, which you redeemed for yourself out of the land of Egypt. Hear my prayer, and have mercy upon your inheritance; turn our mourning into feasting that we may live and sing praise to your name, O Lord; do not destroy the lips of those who praise you." And all Israel cried out mightily, for their death was before their eyes.

Esther’s Prayer:
Then Queen Esther, seized with deadly anxiety, fled to the Lord. She took off her splendid apparel and put on the garments of distress and mourning, and instead of costly perfumes she covered her head with ashes and dung, and she utterly humbled her body; every part that she loved to adorn she covered with her tangled hair. She prayed to the Lord God of Israel, and said:
"O my Lord, you only are our King; help me, who am alone and have no helper but you, for my danger is in my hand. Ever since I was born I have heard in the tribe of my family that you, O Lord, took Israel out of all the nations, and our ancestors from among all their forebears, for an everlasting inheritance, and that you did for them all that you promised. And now we have sinned before you, and you have handed us over to our enemies because we glorified their gods. You are righteous, O Lord! And now they are not satisfied that we are in bitter slavery, but they have covenanted with their idols to abolish what your mouth has ordained, and to destroy your inheritance, to stop the mouths of those who praise you and to quench your altar and the glory of your house, to open the mouths of the nations for the praise of vain idols, and to magnify forever a mortal king.

O Lord, do not surrender your scepter to what has no being; and do not let them laugh at our downfall; but turn their plan against them, and make an example of him who began this against us. Remember, O Lord; make yourself known in this time of our affliction, and give me courage, O King of the gods and Master of all dominion! Put eloquent speech in my mouth before the lion, and turn his heart to hate the man who is fighting against us, so that there may be an end of him and those who agree with him. But save us by your hand, and help me, who am alone and have no helper but you, O Lord.

You know all things, and you know that I hate the splendor of the wicked and abhor the bed of the uncircumcised and of any alien. You know my necessity—that I abhor the sign of my proud position, which is upon my head on days when I appear in public; I abhor it like a filthy rag, and I do not wear it on the days when I am at leisure. And your servant has not eaten at Haman’s table, and I have not honored the king’s feast or drunk the wine of libations. Your servant has had no joy since the day that I was brought here until now, except in you, O Lord God of Abraham. O God, whose might is over all, hear the voice of the despairing, and save us from the hands of evildoers. And save me from my fear!"

On the third day, when she finished her prayer, Esther took off the garments in which she had worshiped, and arrayed herself in her splendid attire. Majestically adorned, and having invoked the aid of the all-seeing God and Savior, she took two maids with her; on one she leaned gently for support, while the other followed, carrying her train. She was radiant with perfect beauty and appeared happy, as if beloved, but her heart was frozen with fear. When she had gone through all the doors, she stood before the king; he was seated on his royal throne, clothed in his full majesty, all covered with gold and precious stones. He was most terrifying. Lifting his face, flushed with splendor, he looked at her in fierce anger. The queen faltered, turned pale and faint, and collapsed on the head of the maid who went in front of her. Then God changed the spirit of the king to gentleness, and in alarm he sprang from his throne, took her in his arms until she came to herself, and comforted her with soothing words. He said, "What is it, Esther? I am your husband. Take courage; you shall not die, for our law applies only to our subjects. Come near." Then he raised the golden scepter and touched her neck with it; he embraced her and said, "Speak to me." She said to him, "I saw you, my lord, like an angel of God, and my heart was shaken with fear at your glory. For you are wonderful, my lord, and your countenance is full of grace." And while she was speaking, she fainted and fell. The king was agitated, and all his servants tried to comfort her.
verses.comment: This deeply emotional and theologically rich passage (found in the Greek additions to Esther) highlights Mordecai’s and Esther’s urgent appeals to God, emphasizing divine sovereignty, the unique calling of Israel as God's inheritance, and the necessity of humble repentance in desperate times (cf. Daniel 9:4–19; Psalm 44), while also illustrating the inner spiritual struggle behind Esther’s brave public role.

verses.text: And when the king saw Queen Esther standing in the court, she won favor in his sight; and he held out to Esther the golden scepter that was in his hand. Then Esther approached and touched the tip of the scepter.
verses.comment: This verse narrates Esther's courageous approach and the king’s favorable response, highlighting themes of divine providence and royal protocol; the touching of the scepter symbolizes acceptance and access to the king’s presence.

verses.text: Then the king asked her, "What is it, Queen Esther? What do you wish? Even if it is half of the kingdom, it will be granted to you."
verses.comment: The king's extravagant offer echoes other royal promises (1 Kings 2:6; Matthew 14:7), representing a trust and generosity extended to those closest to the throne. This prefigures the abundant grace bestowed through intercession.

verses.text: Esther answered, "If it pleases the king, let the king and Haman come today to the banquet I have prepared for him."
verses.comment: Esther invites the king and his adviser to a banquet, presenting hospitality similar to divine feasts (Psalm 23:5). The meal setting hints at spiritual nourishment and foreshadows later biblical banquets associated with the kingdom.

verses.text: Then the king said, "Bring Haman quickly, so that we may do what Esther has asked." So the king and Haman went to the banquet that Esther prepared.
verses.comment: The hasty preparation and obedience to Esther’s invitation parallels Abraham’s hospitality (Genesis 18:6), emphasizing the importance of responding swiftly to sacred moments.

verses.text: While they drank wine, the king asked Esther, "What is your petition? It shall be granted to you. What is your request? Even up to half the kingdom, it will be done."
verses.comment: The sharing of wine aligns with biblical imagery of joy and covenant (Psalm 104:15). The king’s repeated offer shows his willingness to answer petitions, a reminder of God’s generosity to those who ask in faith (Luke 11:9-13).

verses.text: Esther replied, "My petition and my request is this:
verses.comment: Esther’s humility and respect as she presents her case is reminiscent of the reverence shown in prayerful petition (Psalm 21:2). It reflects faithful reliance on wise mediation in approaching authority.

verses.text: "If I have found favor in the sight of the king, and if it pleases the king to grant my petition and fulfill my request, let the king and Haman come tomorrow to the banquet that I will prepare for them. Then I will do as the king has said."
verses.comment: Esther employs patience and wisdom, inviting the king to a second banquet. This two-step approach signifies discernment and devotion, at times necessary to convey grave matters. The repeated inviting hints at persistent prayer (Matthew 7:7-8) and the role of grace in granting favor.

verses.text: Haman went out that day joyful and with a glad heart. But when Haman saw Mordecai at the king’s gate, and Mordecai neither rose nor trembled before him, Haman was filled with fury against Mordecai.
verses.comment: Haman’s pride contrasts sharply with Mordecai’s steadfastness; Haman’s anger mirrors the reactions of the wicked against the righteous (Psalm 112:10, Proverbs 29:27). This foreshadows the enduring tension between evil and those who remain faithful.

verses.text: Nevertheless, Haman restrained himself and went to his house. There he called for his friends and his wife Zeresh.
verses.comment: Haman’s restraint is temporary and fueled by pride. His preference for seeking counsel from family and friends reflects the biblical theme of seeking advice, but in a spirit of self-interest (Proverbs 13:10).

verses.text: Then Haman recounted to them the glory of his riches, the number of his sons, and how the king had promoted him above the officials and servants of the king.
verses.comment: Haman’s boasting of wealth, family, and high status points to the emptiness of earthly glory without humility (Psalm 49:16-17, Luke 12:15). It contrasts with biblical teaching about true riches found in service and self-sacrifice.

verses.text: Moreover, Haman added, "Queen Esther invited no one but me to come with the king to the banquet she prepared, and tomorrow I am also invited by her together with the king."
verses.comment: Haman dwells on his exclusivity, revealing self-centered pride. The emphasis on personal invitation juxtaposes humility before God and the dangers of arrogance (Psalm 36:2).

verses.text: Yet all this avails me nothing, so long as I see Mordecai the Jew sitting at the king’s gate."
verses.comment: Haman’s obsessive resentment toward Mordecai reflects the destructive nature of pride; despite all his honors and wealth, he cannot find satisfaction while his enemy endures—a theme seen in Proverbs 14:30 and throughout wisdom literature on envy’s corrosive effect.

verses.text: Then Zeresh his wife and all his friends said to him, "Let a gallows fifty cubits high be made, and in the morning, ask the king to have Mordecai hanged on it. Then go joyfully with the king to the banquet." This suggestion pleased Haman; so he ordered the gallows to be made.
verses.comment: The plot against Mordecai displays premeditated evil, yet echoes warnings about the fate of those who dig pits for the righteous (Proverbs 26:27). Spiritually, this scene calls to mind persecution of God's people and eventual vindication, an anticipation of the victory of righteousness over evil.
